abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the assessment for both
            projects is satisfactory. However, several sub-components of
            the locomotive and rolling stock system of the Fifth Railway
            Project were technically not met. Furthermore, the Strategic
            Plan Study under the Fourth Railway Project, intended to
            promote a broad-based dialogue between the Bank and the
            Ministry of Railways (MOR), was narrowly defined. The
            lessons learned suggest that, since previous lending
            policies appear to impact fundamentally on both the Bank and
            MOR's approach, particularly that of the Fifth Railway
            Project, regarded as a transitional operation, special
            attention should be given to future operations, upon
            evaluation, and whether meaningful cooperation with MOR was
            achieved. Similarly, the challenge posed to MOR, of
            extensive studies in order to visualize future investment
            requirements, was ambitious. Therefore, evaluations should
            consider whether they really enhanced MOR's
            contribution to the transport sector. Complex operations,
            requiring highly professional skills, may cause unexpected
            expenses, or further contribute to inadequate
            implementation. The suggestion is, to specifically target
            the assistance to transport objectives, and attain
            efficiency and cost-effectiveness. However, MOR's
            reluctance to an involvement in broader strategic planning,
            namely technical assistance, should be brought to terms, for
            full support and commitment.
